1987000 3742000 3990000 1974000 1213000 803000 8595000 1710000 3549000 3336000 1478000 1078000 780000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Depreciation</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">During the three months ended March 31, </font><font style="display: inline;">2016 and 2015, Crocs </font><font style="display: inline;">recorded </font><font style="display: inline;">$3.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$4.7&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">million, respectively, in depreciation expense of which </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.4</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.</font><font style="display: inline;">6</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, respectively, was recorded in &#x2018;Cost of sales,&#x2019; with the remaining amounts recorded in &#x2018;Selling, general and administrative expenses&#x2019; on the condensed consolidated statements of operations. As of March 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015, accumulated depreciation </font><font style="display: inline;">was </font><font style="display: inline;">$101.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">$97.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 194391000 6459000 1980000 34219000 21859000 668000 5036000 98390000 7981000 7277000 667000 1655000 1798000 6402000 282814000 10248000 1727000 8959000 34625000 20368000 668000 7320000 109340000 20719000 7382000 1903000 1515000 54028000 4012000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">7</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">Crocs transacts business in various foreign countries and is therefore exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risk inherent in revenues, costs, and monetary assets and liabilities denominated in non-functional currencies. In general, Crocs enters into foreign currency exchange forward contracts and currency swap derivative instruments to selectively protect against volatility in the value of non-functional currency denominated monetary assets and liabilities, and of future cash flows caused by changes in foreign currency exchange rates. As these derivative instruments do not qualify as hedging instruments under the accounting standards for derivatives and hedging, they are recorded at fair value as a derivative asset or liability on the balance sheet with their corresponding change in fair value recognized in 'Foreign currency transaction </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">gain (</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">loss</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">)</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">, net' in the </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">condensed </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">consolidated statements of operations. For purposes of the cash flow statement, Crocs classifies the cash flows from derivative instruments at settlement from undesignated instruments in the same category as the cash flows from the related hedged items, generally within 'Cash provided by (used in) operating activities'.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">The following table summarizes the notional amounts of outstanding foreign currency exchange contracts as of March 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015. The notional amounts of the derivative financial instruments shown below are denominated in their U.S. Dollar equivalents and represent the amount of all contracts of the foreign currency specified. These notional values do not necessarily represent amounts exchanged by the parties and, therefore, are not a direct measure of the Company's exposure to the foreign currency exchange risks.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <div &nbsp;-</font></p> </td> </tr> </table></div><hr style="border-bottom-style:solid;width:25%;height:.6pt; ;color:#000000" align="left"></hr> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-size:9pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;;"> (1)</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;font-size:9pt;">Represents stores with partially and fully </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">depreciated</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;font-size:9pt;"> assets.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;color:#000000;">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">9</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. STOCK</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">-BASED COMPENSATION</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Stock-based compensation expense is based on the grant date fair value and is recognized on a straight-line basis over the applicable vesting period. During the three months ended </font><font style="display: inline;">March 31</font><font style="display: inline;">, 2016 and 2015, Crocs recorded </font><font style="display: inline;">$2.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$2.9 </font><font style="display: inline;">million, respectively, of pre-tax stock-based compensation expense, of which </font><font style="display: inline;">$2.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$2.9 </font><font style="display: inline;">million, respectively, is included in selling, general and administrative expense, and </font><font style="display: inline;">the remainder included </font><font style="display: inline;">in cost of sales on the condensed consolidated statements of operations. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Stock Option Activity</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">A summary of Crocs&#x2019; stock option activity as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2016 is presented below: </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;background-color:lime;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="middle" style="width:12.08%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #auto;height:12.75pt;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap">9.63&nbsp; </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The total grant date fair value of RSAs vested during the three months ended </font><font style="display: inline;">March 31</font><font style="display: inline;">, &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">2016 and 2015 was less than </font><font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">0.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">March 31</font><font style="display: inline;">, 2016, Crocs had less than </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;"> of total unrecognized stock-based compensation expense related to non-vested</font><font style="display: inline;">, time-based</font><font style="display: inline;"> restricted stock awards, net of expected forfeitures. As of March 31, 2016, the unvested RSAs are expected to be amortized over the remaining weighted average period </font><font style="display: inline;">of </font><font style="display: inline;">0.19</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;years.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The total grant date fair value of RSUs vested during the three months ended March 31, 2016 and 2015 was </font><font style="display: inline;">$5.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$6.5</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively. As of March 31, 2016, Crocs had </font><font style="display: inline;">$23.6</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million of total unrecognized stock-based compensation expense related to unvested restricted stock units, net of expected forfeitures, of which </font><font style="display: inline;">$15.5</font><font style="display: inline;"> million is related to time-based awards and </font><font style="display: inline;">$8.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million is related to performance-based awards. As of March 31, 2016, the unvested RSUs are expected to be amortized over the remaining weighted average period of </font><font style="display: inline;">2.21</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;years, which consists of a remaining weighted average period of </font><font style="display: inline;">2.23</font><font style="display: inline;"> years related to performance-based awards and a remaining weighted average period of </font><font style="display: inline;">2.19</font><font style="display: inline;"> years related to time-based awards.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 3000000 3000000 -0.08 0.07 -0.08 0.07 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Earnings per Share</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Basic and diluted earnings per common share (&#x201C;EPS&#x201D;) is presented using the two-class method, which is an earnings allocation formula that determines earnings per share for common stock and any participating securities according to dividend rights and participation rights in undistributed earnings. Under the two-class method, EPS is computed by dividing the sum of distributed and undistributed earnings attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period. A participating security is a security that may participate in undistributed earnings with common stock had those earnings been distributed in any form. The Company&#x2019;s Series A convertible preferred stock (&#x201C;Series A preferred stock&#x201D;) issued in 2014 represents participating securities as holders of the Series A preferred stock are entitled to receive any and all dividends declared or paid on common stock on an as-converted basis. In addition, shares of the Company&#x2019;s non-vested restricted stock and restricted stock unit awards are</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">considered participating securities as they represent unvested share-based payment awards containing non-forfeitable rights to dividends. As such, these participating securities must be included in the computation of EPS pursuant to the two-class method on a pro-rata, as-converted basis. Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution from securities that could share in the Company&#x2019;s earnings. In addition, the dilutive effect of each participating security, if any, is calculated using the more dilutive of the two-class method described above. This method assumes that the securities remain in their current form, or the if-converted method, which assumes conversion to common stock as of the beginning of the reporting date. Anti-dilutive securities are excluded from diluted EPS</font><font style="display: inline;">. See </font><font style="display: inline;">Note 11&#x2014;Earnings Per Share</font><font style="display: inline;"> for further discussion.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">1</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">1</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. following table illustrates the basic and diluted EPS</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">computations for the three months ended March 31, 2016 and <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:12.88%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">Diluted EPS is calculated using the two-class </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">method for options and RSUs and the if-converted method for Series&nbsp;A preferred stock. For the three months ended March 31, 2016 and 2015, </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">1.9</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;million and</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">2.3</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;million</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> options and RSUs, respectively, were excluded </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">from</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> the calculation of diluted EPS under the two-class method because the effect would be anti-dilutive. The Series&nbsp;A preferred shares were excluded </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">from</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> the calculation of diluted EPS under the if-converted method because the effect would be anti-dilutive. If converted, Series&nbsp;A preferred stock would represent </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">approximately </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">15.8%</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> of the Company's</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> common stock outstanding or </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">13.8</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;million additional common shares, as of March&nbsp;31, 2016. See Note&nbsp;1</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">2</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&#x2014;Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock for further details regarding the preferred share offering.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Stock Repurchase Plan Authorizations</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">Crocs continues to evaluate options to maximize the returns on its cash and maintain an appropriate capital structure, including, among other alternatives, repurchases of common stock. On December&nbsp;26, 2013, </font><font style="display: inline;">Crocs' board of directors (the &#x201C;Board&#x201D;) approved </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">the repurchase of up to </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$350.0</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;million of the Company's common stock. The number, price, structure, and timing of the repurchases will be at the Company's sole discretion and future repurchases will be evaluated by the Company depending on market conditions, liquidity needs,</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> any restrictions under the Company&#x2019;s debt arrangements,</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> and other factors. Share repurchases may be made in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions. The repurchase authorization does not have an expiration date and does not obligate Crocs to acquire any particular amount of its common stock. The Board may suspend, modify, or terminate the repurchase program at any time without prior notice.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">During the three months ended March 31, 2016, Crocs </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">had no </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">repurchase</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">of shares </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">under the publicly-announced repurchase plan. As of March 31, 2016, subject to certain restrictions on repurchases under the Company&#x2019;s revolving credit facility, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Crocs had </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$118.7</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million remaining under the repurchase authorizations.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> -0.139 0.221 -9429000 6367000 20973000 22556000 P2Y4M13D P2Y2M23D P2Y2M9D P2Y2M16D 600000 8100000 15500000 23600000 100000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">6</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Recurring Fair Value Measurements</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">GAAP provides for a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to the valuation techniques used to measure fair value into three broad levels. Level 1 inputs are quoted market prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the reporting entity has the ability to access at the measurement date. Level 2 inputs are inputs other than quoted market prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly. Level 3 inputs are unobservable inputs for the asset or liability.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As of March 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015, our assets subject to fair value measurements consisted solely of cash equivalents of </font><font style="display: inline;">$7.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">$7.5</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively, which are Level 1 assets</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">, and foreign currency derivative </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">assets</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> of </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$1.3</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">million and </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">liabilities of </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$0.1</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">million, respectively, which are L</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">evel 2 assets. The Company's Level </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">1 assets are classified in the </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">condensed </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">consolidated balance sheets as 'Cash and cash equivalents' and 'Prepaid expenses </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">and other assets'. </font><font style="display: inline;">As of March 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015</font><font style="display: inline;">, t</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">he Level </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">2 assets</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> or liabilities</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> are classified in the </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">condensed </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">consolidated balance sheets as </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&#x2018;</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">Prepaid expenses and other assets</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&#x2019; and </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">'Accrued expenses and other liabilities'</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">, respectively</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Non-Recurring Fair Value Measurements</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The majority of the Company&#x2019;s non-finan</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">cial instruments, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">inventories, property and equipment, and intangible assets, are</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> Level 3 assets and are</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> not required to be carried at fair value on a recurring basis. However, if certain triggering events occur such that a non-financial instrument is required to be evaluated for impairment and the carrying value is not recoverable, the carrying value would be adjusted to the lower of its cost or fair value and an impairment charge would be recorded. During the three months ended March 31, 2016, Crocs recorded </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">0.2</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million in impairment charges associated with the Company&#x2019;s retail locations.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">During the three months ended </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">March 31, 2015</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">,</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> the Company had no impairment charges </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">associated wit</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">h the Company&#x2019;s retail locations or inventory write-down charges.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;"></font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 95882000 3498000 5135000 82596000 4016000 637000 100462000 3723000 5219000 86771000 4113000 636000 9350000 14233000 10943000 13210000 14812000 16792000 177882000 3498000 6892000 162700000 4016000 776000 179802000 3723000 6879000 164451000 4113000 636000 82000000 1757000 80104000 139000 79340000 1660000 77680000 1300000 100000 494000 -1247000 1751000 5613000 -5723000 -3509000 1973000 2611000 500000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">4. GOODWILL &amp; INTANGIBLE ASSETS</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The 2016 and 2015, amortization expense recorded for intangible assets with finite lives was </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$4.9</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">million and </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$5.</font><font style="display: &#x2018;Selling, general and administrative expenses&#x2019; </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">on the condensed consolidated statements of operations. As of March 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015, accumulated </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">amortization was $100.5 million and</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> $95.9 million, respectively.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 127370000 129366000 193000 169000 24000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Asset Impairments</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Crocs periodically evaluates all of its long-lived assets for impairment when events or circumstances would indicate the carrying value of a long-lived asset may not be fully recoverable. </font><font style="display: inline;">The following table summarizes retail asset impairment charges by reportable operating segment for the three months ended March 31, 2016 and 2015 related to certain underperforming stores that were unlikely to generate sufficient cash flows to fully recover the carrying value of the stores&#x2019; assets over the remaining economic life or lease terms of those assets:</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: INCOME TAXES</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">During the three months ended </font><font style="display: inline;">March 31</font><font style="display: inline;">, 2016, the Company recognized income tax expense of $2.9 million on pre-tax income of $1</font><font style="display: inline;">3.1 million. This represents an effective income tax rate of </font><font style="display: inline;">22.1%</font><font style="display: inline;">. &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">For the same period in 2015, the Company recognized income tax expense of $0.3 million on a pre-tax loss of $2.1 million</font><font style="display: inline;">, representing an effective tax rate of </font><font style="display: inline;">(13.9%)</font><font style="display: inline;">. &nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;background-color:;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The change in effective tax rate is primarily due to an increase in profitability in various jurisdictions, compared to the same period in 2015. The Company&#x2019;s effective income tax rate, for each period presented, differs from the federal U.S. statutory rate primarily due to differences in income tax rates between U.S. and foreign jurisdictions. There were no significant or unusual discrete tax items during the quarter. The Company had unrecognized tax benefits of </font><font style="display: inline;">$5.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$5.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million at March 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015, respectively, and the Company does not expect any significant changes in this balance in the next twelve months.</font><font style="display: inline;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;"></font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 7101000 2648000 10233000 10001000 295000 2905000 42783000 18487000 78436000 69763000 7256000 -1498000 18955000 14383000 2628000 -1227000 -2541000 8312000 -272000 1760000 946000 297000 311000 82297000 79651000 84270000 82262000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;color:#000000;">Transactions with Affiliates</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&#xFEFF;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">The Company receives inventory cou</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">nt services from RGIS, LLC (&#x201C;RGIS&#x201D;), a wholly-</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">owned subsidiary of </font><font style="display: inline;">Blackstone Capital Partners VI L.P. none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #auto;height:0.75pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:center;font-family:Times New Roman;height:0.75pt;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:14.44%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:14.46%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #auto;height:12.75pt;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap">186,113&nbsp; </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:02.12%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none
